  physical_appearance: The book is hardcover and its front cover is predominantly sepia in colour. There is an image of a scimitar in a decorated square border at the top centre of the front cover. The title and author of the book are displayed inside this square border as well. On the book\u0027s spine
 the same images are displayed
 but they are enclosed in a rectangular border instead.  There are no visible tears and the book looks slightly worn out near its top.

  sgcool_label_text: \The Further Side of Silence is a collection of short stories by Hugh Clifford
 British Resident of Penang (1896-1900)
 Governor of North Borneo (1900-1901) and Governor of the Straits Settlements (1927-1930). The short stories in this collection
 while fictional
 are based on Clifford\u0027s personal experiences in the Malay Peninsula. In his preface
 Clifford claims that these stories \\faithfully reproduce the conditions of life as they existed in the Malayan Peninsula before the white man took a hand in the government of the native states

metadata.physical_appearance: The book is hardcover and its front cover is predominantly sepia in colour. There is an image of a scimitar in a decorated square border at the top centre of the front cover. The title and author of the book are displayed inside this square border as well. On the book's spine, the same images are displayed, but they are enclosed in a rectangular border instead.  There are no visible tears and the book looks slightly worn out near its top.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: "The Further Side of Silence is a collection of short stories by Hugh Clifford, British Resident of Penang (1896-1900), Governor of North Borneo (1900-1901) and Governor of the Straits Settlements (1927-1930). The short stories in this collection, while fictional, are based on Clifford's personal experiences in the Malay Peninsula. In his preface, Clifford claims that these stories ""faithfully reproduce the conditions of life as they existed in the Malayan Peninsula before the white man took a hand in the government of the native states
